awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Proposal: MSB-FRA: Causes, consequences, and cross-scale linkages of environment-driven phenological mismatch across three trophic levels
awd_abstract_narration:
The timing and synchrony of seasonal events presents real challenges in the natural world. Migratory birds coordinate their departure from wintering grounds in Central or South America to arrive at North American breeding grounds at just the right time. Too early and they risk experiencing severe weather from late frosts or blizzards. Too late and they risk missing the peak in early spring insects that they depend on to successfully raise offspring. For their part, insects such as butterflies also benefit when their emergence coincides with the springtime flush of new plant growth. The timing of spring has been shifting earlier in recent years, and this raises the possibility of mismatches in spring timing between birds, insects, and plants. A few local scale studies have suggested that such mismatches may be responsible for long-term population declines for some species, but the extent of this problem, especially over large areas remains unknown. In this project, the research team will combine information on springtime weather, satellite imagery on plant emergence, and multiple large-scale citizen science data on birds, butterflies, and caterpillars to perform a comprehensive evaluation of mismatches in seasonal timing between interacting species. This work is critical for understanding the potential impacts of continued shifts in seasonality on living systems. The work will also engage K-college students and the public through a new citizen science program, educational units, and outreach events focused on learning about the timing of seasonal changes. 
 
The proposed research will be the first attempt to examine phenological mismatch across three trophic levels at a semi-continental extent. Local-scale studies have documented specific instances of phenological mismatch but fail to inform how mismatch consequences propagate across spatial, temporal, or trophic scales. Birds and butterflies provide the most expansive, long-term and detailed macroecological data sets on distribution, diversity, and demography. The project will unite multiple large-scale citizen science datasets for these taxa with targeted field data collection, and remotely-sensed climate and vegetation data layers, to examine the cross-scale and multi-trophic interactions that connect shifting thermal environments, phenological mismatch, and fitness consequences. This will be accomplished by: (1) assembling and uniting continental and regional monitoring and citizen-science databases for Lepidoptera and birds; (2) building spatio-temporal models in order to assess drivers of phenology, calculate direct metrics of phenological mismatch across trophic levels, and evaluate fitness and population consequences of those mismatches; and (3) testing the ability of generated models to predict phenology and population trends for focal birds and Lepidoptera across eastern North America as a function of tri-trophic phenological mismatch. Taking a macro-scale perspective on phenological mismatch is critical for understanding the range-wide impacts of sustained trends in seasonal timing. In addition to answering critical research questions on phenological mismatch the team will extend the impacts of their work through both specific training opportunities and broad-based education and outreach efforts.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on how climate is shifting the timing of ecological events such as emergence of plants, insects, and migratory birds. While the field of climate change ecology has focused mostly on species’ range shifts, there has been comparatively less focus on how changes of days or weeks in seasonal timing can influence species, communities, and ecosystems. Recently, this phenological research has shifted to focus on how differential emergence timing may cause phenological “mismatches” (e.g., between plants, insects, and insectivorous birds). If, for example, insects shifted earlier in warmer springs, but plants did not, then those insects may emerge in a world with nothing to eat. This could depress insect populations which could impact the ability of migratory birds to successfully rear offspring during the summer breeding season. The vast majority of phenological mismatch studies to date use on-the-ground data collection which is extremely valuable but necessarily occurs over small spaces and short time periods. The goal of our project was to scale up these trophic interactions and determine how they play out across a larger scale. This work necessitated a highly collaborative and multi-disciplinary group of researchers. Here, I summarize the collective outcomes of the entire collaboration (see associated NSF awards 2033263 and 1702708) and then focus on the specific achievements of the Georgetown team.

The ultimate focus of this collaboration was birds as a primary response variable to show how small-scale ecological dynamics can be magnified at higher trophic levels. The bird group demonstrated a novel conceptual link between range shifts and phenological shifts, including between phenology, demography, and environmental gradients. Work to make the final links between insect and bird phenology continued under supplemental funding for NSF award 2033263.  

Georgetown focused largely on climate, vegetation, and insect phenology. Unlike vegetation dynamics, some of which are captured through satellite imagery, there are no large-scale spatiotemporal data layers that capture insect distributions. Our goal was to create data layers of relative insect biomass using butterflies as a proxy. Butterflies are second only to birds in terms of nation-wide volunteer monitoring. Our initial work included several methodological advances combining multiple data sources on butterflies in North America.  We also focused on how timing of both plants and climate drive phenology, abundance and declines of butterflies. These results are especially relevant with the recently demonstrated pattern of global insect decline, termed the “insect apocalypse”. Our research showed that butterfly timing is indeed driven largely by the combination of temperature and vegetation green up. We also demonstrated that when regional temperature and green up are decoupled relative to normal patterns (itself a form of phenological mismatch), then butterfly abundance declines.

Although this study was broadly focused on tri-tropic interactions and birds in particular, the Georgetown team also focused on how phenology influences the iconic monarch butterfly in its southern (spring) and northern (summer) migratory breeding grounds. We showed that milkweed (their host plant) generally emerges in the spring right before monarchs begin arriving from Mexico, but there is only a small gap in timing. On the summer grounds, milkweeds emerge well before arriving monarchs. These results suggest that spring, but not summer, phenological mismatch may contribute to population declines in the future.  

Another goal of the Georgetown team was to provide a framework for projecting phenological dynamics into the future using global climate change models. Our team made substantial progress in advancing emerging methods for implementing large-scale, long-term ecological projections. This included linking vegetation green up of eastern forests to yearly temperature patterns. We also implemented our most detailed projections on animal responses by focusing on our best-studied species, the monarch butterfly.

Work on this project involved the mentoring of many post-doctoral scholars, graduate and undergraduate students. Throughout this project, multi-level mentoring took place in individual labs, but also across collaborative institutions thus providing training in the critical skill of fostering effective and equitable collaborations. In terms of research productivity, the personnel at Georgetown led or were involved as coauthors on 11 papers that were published during or shortly after this reporting period and 5 papers that are currently under review.  

Phenology is the most apparent impact of climate change on the natural world. People notice the change in weather, but also how it associates to visible signs of earlier spring budburst, insect activity, and the arrival of migratory birds. Our research ties these factors together and can show the more complex downstream consequences of climate to a public that is increasingly concerned about these accelerating changes in the natural world.
